Chapter 3 (of 3): Encouraging the Mind
In cultivating the stages of the path, by what means does one rectify one's mind?
I have heard this before:
In the past there was a king who selected a wise person from the country to be his chief minister.

At that time the king devised immeasurable skillful means and wisdom to select a person who was intelligent and knowledgeable, whose aspirations were magnanimous, who was majestic but not violent, and who was fully endowed with fame and virtue.
The king wanted to test him to see what he was like,

so he wanted to inflict a serious crime on this person. He ordered the officials to fill a bowl with oil and have him carry it from the north gate to the south gate, twenty li away from the city to a garden called Amusement, and have him take it there. If a person carrying the oil spilled a drop, he would be beheaded without further questioning.
Then he spoke a verse:
following my teaching and not discarding the oil,ğŸ”½I will respect this person as I would myself,
discarding the oil on the way, I will cut off his head.
At that time, the ministers received the king's weighty teaching, filled a bowl with oil and gave it to the person.
Holding it in both hands, he was very sorrowful and thought to himself:

'The oil is full in the vessel, the people in the city are many, the roads are filled with carts and horses, and the onlookers fill the streets, just like water that is still but is blown by the wind, and the water waves rise;
people are also like this, their minds are not at ease.
' He withdrew and thought to himself:
'There is not a single person who encourages me, saying not to be afraid!
This vessel of oil is held for seven steps, and it is still not possible to go, let alone the number of li!'
This person was confused and did not know where to go, his mind was fearful.
Then he spoke in verse:
Seeing people, elephants, horses, and carriages, like a great wind blowing on water, the mind is like this.
With a fearful mind, not understanding, how can one ultimately understand this matter?
The person thinks in his mind:
'I am now definitely going to die, there is no doubt about it!
If I can hold the bowl and not let the oil spill, and reach the garden, then I will live!
I must concentrate, if I see right and wrong and do not waver, only thinking of the oil bowl and not elsewhere, then I can cross over!'
Then the person walks calmly and slowly.
At that time, the ministers, soldiers, and countless hundreds of thousands of onlookers follow and watch him, like clouds rising and surrounding Mount Tai.
Then he chants a verse, saying:
The person holding the bowl, with a firm mind, sees the various onlookers on the road,
Surrounded by the crowd, following him, like a great cloud rising over the rivers and seas.
When that person held up the bowl, the sound spread everywhere and was heard by all. Countless people came and gathered, and the crowd all said:
'Look at this person's clothes, appearance, and movements. He must be a death row inmate.
' The news of this person reached his home, and his parents and relatives all rushed to where their child was and wailed and grieved.
But that person was single-minded, not paying attention to his parents, siblings, wife, or other relatives. His mind was on the oil bowl, with no other thoughts.
Then, he spoke in verse:
The child wept with tears like a spring, crying and lamenting in various ways,
His mind was fearful and he did not heed his relatives. He was single-minded and held the bowl with determination.
The crowd discussed and called out to each other like this, again and again.

At that time, the people of the entire country gathered, and the onlookers were so crowded that their shouts shook the ground. They rushed to each other, trampling and rising again, and they stepped on each other so closely that there was no room. The man's mind was focused and he did not see the crowd.
Then, he spoke in verse:
The crowd shouted without rest, following each other in front and behind, not allowing any sound to be heard.
He held the oil bowl without looking at all, like hail and rain in the sky, causing no harm.
The onlookers said again:

There was a woman who came, upright and beautiful, with a majestic and radiant countenance unmatched in the entire country, like the full moon shining alone among the stars. Her appearance was like a lotus flower walking on the royal road, her appearance majestic and her complexion surpassing that of humans. She was like a jade maiden, or like the wife of the Heavenly King of the Thirty-three Heavens named Huli, upright and beautiful, respected by all the gods and people.
This girl is so radiant, able to dance in eight ways, her voice is clear and harmonious, and everyone who hears it is delighted.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Her movements are graceful, her singing and dancing do not transgress the Dharma,
Her mind is filled with joy, and she moves everyone.
Her singing voice is sorrowful, her body is swaying,
Not too fast or slow, her attire is proper and dignified.
The seven subtle sounds, the extraordinary descriptions, are fifty,
The three places are pure, the palace and business notes harmonize with each other.
From head to toe, her body is adorned with jeweled necklaces,
Her speech is beautiful and elegant, like a rain of sweet dew.
At that time, the man single-mindedly held the bowl, his mind unwavering and unobservant.
The onlookers all said:ğŸ”½This man is truly extraordinary, holding the bowl with a pure mind, not looking left or right, his mind is like a mountain, unmoved by the girl's beauty.
'It is better to see this woman's face today and regret it for the rest of my life than to live a long time without seeing her.'
At that time, although that person heard these words, he single-mindedly held the bowl and did not listen to her words.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
Skillfully and calmly, her dance was most skillful and wonderful,
All people greedily enjoyed it, just like Mara's wife,
She could move even those free from desire, let alone ordinary people;
She came and went by that person's side, but his mind did not waver as he held the bowl.
At that time there was a very drunk elephant that ran wildly into the carriage road. The people said to each other:

'Now the drunk elephant is coming. It will trample and gore us, causing our deaths. This is a demoness who has transformed into the form of an elephant, causing much harm without avoiding men or women;

His body had sores and was rough, like a large thigh with poisonous vapors flowing down. His tongue was red like blood, his belly was on the ground, his lips were hanging down as he walked, and he was unrestrained. His body was smeared with human blood;

He roamed alone without difficulty, advancing and retreating at will, like a king. He looked like a mountain from afar, and his violent roars were like thunder, with his nose raised, angry and furious.
Here is the verse:
The great elephant's strength is very difficult to withstand, his body bleeding like a spring,
Treading on the ground, raising dust and opening his mouth, as if wanting to harm the people.

The elephant was like this, terrifying the onlookers, causing them to flee and scatter. The troops and elephants were destroyed and fled. Everyone who saw it wanted to be frightened to death. He could pull up large trees and trample on the masses. Although he was whipped, he was fearless and difficult to deal with.ğŸ”½Here is the verse:
Here is the verse:
Destroying crowds and herds of elephants, terrifying people or causing death,
Pushing over houses, running away without fear of the driver.
Renowned far and wide, taking toughness as virtue,
Arrogant and unrestrained, unable to endure lofty aspirations.

At that time, those who were sitting in the streets, markets, and shops all hurriedly covered their goods, closed their doors for fear of having their houses destroyed, and people all fled in avoidance;

Moreover, the elephant trainer had no control, his anger and delusion increased even more, and he trampled to death elephants, horses, cows, sheep, pigs, calves, and other animals in the road, and smashed the carts and carriages, scattering them in all directions.
Then he spoke a verse:
Those sitting in the shops all covered their goods, injuring people, livestock, and smashing carts and carriages,
Seeing this, they closed their doors, as if a thief had destroyed a large camp.

Some people saw this and became frightened, not daring to move. Some cried out in resentment, tears streaming down. Some were confused and did not know what to do. Some ran away without even putting on their clothes. Some were so confused they did not know east from west. Some ran like clouds blown by the wind, not knowing where they were going.

Some were so frightened they slapped their bellies on the ground. Some were so desperate they drew their bows and arrows, wanting to shoot. Some held their swords, intending to fight. Some lost their composure and spoke nonsense. Some were so angry their eyes turned red. Some held back their joy at seeing from afar. Even though they held weapons, they could not bring themselves to use them.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Here, some were frightened and terrified, while others wept.
Some were astonished and did not find it difficult, while others held weapons.
Some were so distraught they collapsed on the ground, utterly lost and not knowing themselves.
Having obtained this instability, all is due to seeing the intoxicated elephant.
At that time, there was a person who understood the mantra for taming elephants. He thought to himself:

'According to the method of taming elephants that I have learned, there are generally eight hundred good and bad behaviors. I observe that this elephant does not have any of them. I will now examine from what kind it comes.
There are four upper kinds, is it of the middle kind or the lower kind?'
Having examined and known it, he immediately raised his voice and recited the divine mantra.
Then he spoke in verse:
The Heavenly King bestowed the vajra, I have a subtle language,
Which can remove all arrogance, and make the weak strong.
That person immediately raised his voice and said:
'Those who are enlightened are not arrogant and do not give rise to vexation. They abandon affection and follow the Dharma. It is attained by practicing sincerity and faith!
The elephant abandons arrogance and tames the mind to make it peaceful.'
He spoke these two ancient sage verses:
Lust, anger, and delusion, these three great arrogances in the world,
The true path is free from defilements, and all afflictions are extinguished.
Using that sincere Dharma, practice should be like this,
The great intention to offer to the elephant king, remove delusions and abandon arrogance.

At that time, the elephant heard this correct teaching, immediately abandoned its arrogance and subdued its mind, then followed the original path and returned to the elephant stable, not offending anyone and causing no harm.
The person holding the bowl did not notice the elephant coming or leaving.
Why is that?
Because the mind is focused on fear of death, without any other thoughts.
Then he spoke a verse:
Seeing the elephant like a violent rain, the mind was never disturbed,
Although the rain has stopped, the sky is not delighted either.
That person is also like this, not noticing the elephant coming and going,
Holding the oil bowl with a focused mind, like a treasure to be remembered.

At that time, the onlookers were so crowded that they ran east and west. Because of this, a fire broke out in the city, burning the official palaces, the houses of various treasures, the pavilions, and the high terraces. The magnificent and towering [buildings] spread and connected, like a great mountain that no one could see. The smoke was everywhere, and the fire was still raging.
Then, he spoke in verse:
The city was prosperous and joyful, with well-decorated palaces and houses.
The smoke pervaded everywhere, and the fire blazed like a person who wants to burn.
When the city was on fire, the bees all came out and stung people with their venom. The onlookers were in pain and ran away in surprise;
The men and women, young and old, had distorted faces, disheveled hair, and their jewelry fell off;
Their eyes were red and teary from the smoke, and they saw the fire in the distance, their hearts filled with fear and anxiety, not knowing where to go.
They called out to each other, father and son, brothers, wives and children, and servants, and instructed each other:
'Avoid the fire, stay away from the water, don't fall into the mud pit, and you will be safe.'
Then he spoke a verse:
Anxious and worried, they were unaware, the family members, relatives, and servants,
Riding elephants and horses, they sadly came out, saying there was a great fire to be avoided.
At that time, the officials and soldiers all came to extinguish the fire;
The man was single-mindedly focused on holding the bowl, not letting a single drop fall, unaware of when the fire started or when it was extinguished.
Why is it so?
Because his mind was focused and he had no other thoughts.
Then he spoke a verse:
Many people were confused, like birds encountering fire and flying away,ğŸ”½The fire burned the palace, and smoke billowed like floating clouds.
Their hair disheveled and terrified, they avoided the smoke and fire and ran away;
Single-mindedly focused on the oil bowl, unaware of the fire's arising and extinguishing.
At that time, five-colored clouds arose, and there was a great thunder and lightning in the sky.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Having given rise to a great fog and untimely rain, the wind arose and blew the clouds, making them completely dark.
The sky was filled with impurity, like a herd of wild elephants, the clouds were like this.
At that time, a chaotic wind arose, blowing up dust on the ground, filling the king's road with sand, gravel, tiles, and stones, uprooting trees, breaking branches, and dropping flowers and fruits.
Then, he spoke in verse:
The wind arose, raising dust and spreading everywhere, giving rise to clouds carrying water, covering everywhere.
The violent wind suddenly darkened, and one could not see each other, thunder and lightning struck together, and everyone was startled.
At that time, the great clouds emitted lightning and thunder, and a thunderbolt fell. The peacocks all cried out, and the sky then released rain and dropped hail;
although there were these changes, that person did not hear them.
Why is it so?
Single-mindedly recollecting the oil bowl.
Then, he spoke in verse:
When the elephant was let loose, it was like a great cloud rising,
With hail, fire, and wind falling, uprooting trees and destroying houses.
That person did not see, how could he know what was good or who was evil?
Unaware of the rising wind and clouds, he only watched the full bowl of oil.
At that time, the person held the full bowl of oil, not spilling a drop as he went to the garden.

All the soldiers, ministers, and officials returned to the king's palace and fully told the king about the various difficulties they encountered, but the person single-mindedly held the bowl without moving, not spilling a drop as he reached the garden.
When the king heard their words, he sighed and said:
'This person is difficult to match, a hero among men!
He did not care about his relatives or the jade maidens, nor was he alarmed by the dangers of the great elephant, water, fire, thunder, or lightning.
I heard the sound of thunder and was startled and frightened. Although I made a request, I did not understand his words. Some had their hearts split and died, while others harmed their fetuses.

The people who stood there did not realize it themselves. Although they encountered many difficulties, their minds did not waver. Such a person can accomplish anything. With a mind as strong as this, they will never encounter difficulties. Even if the king of hell punishes them, they can eat diamonds!
The king was delighted and appointed him as a minister.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Seeing weeping relatives and a rampaging drunken elephant,
Although encountering various dangers, his mind did not waver.
The king saw that this person's mind was firm and unmoved,
And out of affection and respect, appointed him as a minister.

At that time, the practitioner's mind is firm and stable. Although encountering good and evil, as well as various dangers and difficulties, their resolve does not waver. They escape the death penalty and, once free, enjoy wealth and longevity.

Practicing the Way, one should control the mind like this. Although there are various afflictions and desires, anger, and ignorance that disturb the faculties, one protects the mind and does not follow them. One focuses the mind on the first [stage] and observes one's own body internally and the bodies of others externally. One does the same with feelings, mind, and dharmas.
Here is the verse:
Just as a person holding a bowl of oil does not move or spill it,
The mind of subtle wisdom is like the ocean, single-mindedly holding the oil vessel.
If a person wishes to study the Way, they should control the mind like this,
The mind filled with virtues and wisdom, eliminating all faults.
Various forms of desire, anger, and ignorance arise,
Those with determination are not negligent, peacefully extinguishing and restraining themselves.
If a person's body has an illness, medicine is used to cure it.
The mind's illness is also like this, the four foundations of mindfulness cure it.
Those whose minds are firm and strong can do this: they can destroy the Snow Mountains with their fingernails, pierce the Golden Mountain with lotus roots, and saw through Mount Sumeru with a saw.

Those who have no faith cannot be diligent, and harbor flattery, negligence, and forgetfulness. Even if they live in the world for a long time, they will never be able to remove the defilements of desire, anger, and ignorance.
Those who have faith, diligence, sincerity, and wisdom, whose minds are firm and strong, can also blow on a mountain and make it shake, let alone remove desire, anger, and ignorance.
Therefore, practitioners who wish to accomplish morality and virtue should have faith, diligence, wisdom, and sincerity, and tame their minds, focusing on the stage of practice.
Here is a verse:
Upright faith and diligence, wisdom without flattery,
Separating the mind from countless defilements.ğŸ”½Gathering the understanding of countless sÅ«tras,
Self-realizing this Buddha's teachings,ğŸ”½Merely taking the essential words,
Distinguishing the meaning in countless ways.ğŸ”½The abode of merit, lofty and majestic,
Like learning relying on a quiet dwelling,ğŸ”½The form of a good treasure in the river of wisdom,
I wish to bow my head to the king of great mountains.ğŸ”½Coming down from the heavens,
Knowing the way without confusion,ğŸ”½The Buddha is born without a womb,
Neither entering nor exiting,ğŸ”½Not experiencing any suffering or distress,
Not attached, not inverted,ğŸ”½Virtuous and weighty, without attachment,
Taking refuge to cross over birth and death.
Those who practice the Way may sometimes be lazy, thinking that the Dharma is subtle, difficult to understand, difficult to comprehend, and cannot be distinguished.
One should recognize the root of suffering, eliminate all habits, realize the cessation of extinction, and cultivate the techniques of mindfulness.
It is like a person who takes a single hair, breaks it into a hundred parts, and then reconnects it as before without any error. Is this very difficult or not?
He replied:
Very difficult!
Very difficult!
One can use magical transformations, various medicines, and incantations to reconnect the hair as before, but the path to nirvana is not established by this.
Although one may not be able to attain the realization of the Way, there should be skillful means.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Always be vigorous and diligent, heading towards the gate of liberation, wishing to understand what is difficult and even more difficult,
Exerting effort, encouraging joy without retreating, like deeply digging the ground to obtain spring water.
One should contemplate in this way:
Nothing is accomplished more quickly than nirvana. It is not sought from others but attained from one's own mind. It is only difficult to obtain from others!
What is difficult to attain through one's own diligent efforts?

One should make this calculation, only using true contemplation to guide and advance one's mind, like coaxing a small child to come to the front by calling out, and then taking the hand and eating the food;
When the small child comes, each finger is pulled apart and nothing is obtained.
The world is like this, with inverted views, taking impermanence as permanence, suffering as happiness, non-self as self, and emptiness as reality.
Abandoning the four inversions, one makes the observation of original non-existence, and then one accords with the Buddha's teachings and admonitions.
Then, he spoke a verse, saying:
People who do not understand original non-existence always calculate happiness and purity,
Like using a rattle to coax a small child.
Then, this person has inversions, and has the thought of self and mine,
One should manifest radiance, like a lamp burning in the dark.
I have hair that cannot last long, is not clean, is not at ease, and is without self;
Observing this, everything is the same.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Encouraging their minds is like a person with clear eyes holding a torch and walking into an empty room, observing that there are no people and nothing to see. Carefully observing is also like this.
Examining the basis of form, seeing impermanence, suffering, no self, and non-body, those who falsely see are bound by themselves.
What difficulty is there in understanding emptiness?
Those who can presently see and hear attain the path of the stream-enterer, once-returner, non-returner, and the unattached, and attain perfect enlightenment.
These people, I am also one of them;
These people attain enlightenment, why is it that I alone do not attain it?
Those who cultivate the path encourage their minds like this, abandoning the four inverted views and focusing on the stage of practice.
Here is the verse:
Hair, body hair, nails, bones, flesh, and various forms and shapes,
The multitude comes to confuse the mind, disturbed by the five aggregates;ğŸ”½Impermanent, suffering, and unstable,
Without self, impure,
The body is like an empty house, the wise observe it thus.
The Buddha was at the PÄá¹­ikÄ tree, Indra offered a hundred flavors,
He was also in ÅšrÄvastÄ«, Prasenajit made offerings,
At the hermitage, rice was prepared, although wheat rice is delicious,
All equally accept it with an impartial mind, bowing to the one without attachment.
Although having eaten this rice, he is not attached to its color,
He also does not give rise to arrogance, abandoning all conceit,
Wherever he receives offerings, it is like crossing a vast road,
Not considering it delicious, therefore I bow in reverence.
At that time, the practitioner should contemplate the food and drink.

Even if there are a hundred flavors and coarse wheat rice, in the belly they are the same without distinction. When food is put in the mouth and chewed, it mixes with saliva and becomes the same as vomit;
If it enters the stomach, the body's fire cooks it, the body's water softens it, and the wind blows it around;

Gradually digested, it falls into the mature stomach. The solid becomes feces, the moist becomes urine, the froth becomes mucus and saliva. The essential flavors in the stomach flow through the channels to nourish the body.

Then it nourishes the hair, body hair, nails, teeth, bones, marrow, blood, flesh, fat, grease, essence, and the head and brain. The external four great elements nourish the internal five sense organs. The sense organs gain strength and grow in the mind, giving rise to desire, anger, and ignorance.
If you want to know this, it is the basis of solid food, and it arises from this.
Here is a verse:
Countless superior flavors are no different when they fall into the stomach.
The changes in the body are equal and impure, so practitioners do not crave food.
Although you should eat, do not seek to be fat, just to sustain life.
It is like a high official catching flying birds, cutting off their wings, and putting them in a cage. He selects the fat ones every day to feed the official kitchen.
At that time, the flying birds gradually decreased day by day. There was a bird who thought to himself:
The fat ones die first. If I become fat, I will die as before.
If I do not eat, I will starve to death.

Now I should eat in moderation, not making my body fat but also not emaciated, so that my body is light and I can come and go without obstruction. I will not be seen and killed by the butcher. My feathers and wings can gradually grow. If I escape from the cage, I can fly away and go wherever I want.

The practitioner should also think like this. Eating just enough to sustain the body and not making the body heavy, eating lightly and comfortably with little sleep, sitting, walking, breathing peacefully, with little urination and defecation, the body relying on practice, with little desire, anger, and ignorance.
The practitioner should contemplate like this:

I do not crave the body or eliminate emotional desires. This body is not essential, with bones and joints supporting each other. Now in this body, it is only filled with impurities and lacks solidity.
It is like an enemy, a useless net, always harboring resentment and injuring relatives and friends. One should analyze it and make offerings and service as if to a king.
How should one do it?

Following the Buddha's teachings, sitting, standing, and walking, preventing calamities and misfortunes, always observing impurities and fully understanding their defilement, nurturing life and practicing the path, like having relatives who cannot be abandoned;

The body is also like this. Bathing, eating, clothing, and covering the body, loving it like a child and always protecting it, not allowing the suffering of cold, warmth, hunger, and thirst, not being bitten by mosquitoes, flies, fleas, or lice.
If there is a rebellious thief, he is arrested and imprisoned. The jailers torture him in various ways:
'For whom did you rob and steal before?
Where do you live?
What did you steal?
Who were your accomplices?
Were you part of a gang?
The five poisons were used to torture him, and he lost consciousness. When he revived, he thought to himself:
What expedient can I use to escape the beating?
His mind suddenly opened up, and he told the jailer:

Far away in a certain country, there is the son of a great elder named Jinjie. All the things I have stolen have been taken to his house. I have lived with him and committed theft together. He is my accomplice.
When the jailer heard this, he arrested the elder's son and put him in the same cell as the previous thief, both of them chained in iron fetters.
At that time, the elder's son received food from home and ate it alone without sharing it with the thief.
The thief became very angry, his eyes bulging and teeth clenched. He broke out in sweat and sighed, wanting to do evil and cause the elder's son to lose his life, let alone eat alone:
Now that I am in control, I will force him not to drink water alone, let alone eat alone!
The son of the householder, having been spoiled and indulged since childhood, could not bear to walk for even a moment, and wanted to go to the back of the house, so he said to the thief:
'Let's go to the toilet together.'
The thief replied:
'Go wherever you want, I can't go there.'
At that time, the son of the householder, feeling extremely pressed, said to the thief:
'There is nothing wrong with my son, he wrongfully dragged me and locked me up in prison;
Now I want to get up a little, but you still won't comply?
If you don't agree to be tied up, I will never report it.
I will pretend to offend you, and you can tell me about it, so I can reflect on my mistakes and apologize for my crimes.'
At that time, the thief replied:
'You are truly innocent, I wrongfully dragged you.
You have many relatives, wanting to escape your crimes, not seeing any punishment, and being allowed to eat and drink, so I wronged you!
You have gifts, but you eat them alone, never sharing them, so I don't comply.'
At that time, the son of the householder then said to the thief:
'I understand your resentment. From now on we will never lose each other again.
If there are gifts sent, first feed your son, and then I will eat myself.
As long as I am alive, I wish to reach home and let my body breathe.'
The thief then followed him.
The next day when the gifts arrived, he ordered the maid:
Bring the food you have and first offer it to your close friend, and then give me what is left of what you have eaten.
At that time, the maid followed the instructions and did as she was told. When the messenger returned home, he reported in detail to the elder.
When the elder heard this, he became angry and went to the prison the next day to tell his son:
You were born into a noble clan, yet you associate with rebellious thieves and evil people, and become close to them, not realizing at all that this will lead to your being dragged to prison.
His son replied:
What my father says is true. I do not respect this person and consider him a close friend!
I know very well that he is a thief!

I wanted to go to the toilet, but he wouldn't let me. My body was heavy, my belly was swollen, my eyes rolled back, my ears were deaf, I had a headache, my back was splitting, my ribs felt like they were being pulled out, my chest was full of air, my breathing was about to stop, my mind was confused and I couldn't tell my own direction, my joints felt like they were coming apart, my bones and body ached, my life was about to end, evil things were above me, sweat came out and I was short of breath.
The thief said to me:
If you can follow me like a patient follows a doctor, then it will be possible.
First feed me, then eat yourself, and I will follow you.
Because of greed for my body and life, I became close to him!
Just like the son of a wealthy family fully knows that this thief is an enemy!

Because of the exhaustion of afflictions, externally one manifests as if close and intimate, but internally one is distant and thin. Knowing that the four elements are impermanent things, the four matters increase and decrease, and one is not at ease. Like a poisonous snake, like an illusion, a mirage, a water moon, or an echo in the mountains, one understands the body in this way.

The practitioner also understands this, knowing that the five aggregates are all enemies and thieves. Using clothing and food to nourish the body and prevent harm, diligently practicing day and night as if putting out a fire on one's head. Not by being lazy and negligent can one accomplish the Way and virtue, reaching the state of no-action, and crossing over the beginning and end of the three realms.

Chapter 12: Subduing and Mastering the Senses (3) Sutra on the Stages of Concentration Practice, Chapter 12: Subduing and Mastering the Senses. The practitioner, whose desires, anger, and ignorance are weak, if not indulging in worldly affairs, is not harmed. Not yet accomplishing the Way and virtue, not yet seeing the truth, yet claiming to have attained it!

Thus, the practitioner admonishes their mind and thoughts, letting them dwell on thoughts of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, and becoming attached to the five aggregates, not yet accomplishing what needs to be done.
If the mind does not follow the five aggregates and hindrances, then one knows they have attained the Way;
If the mind is confused and follows the desires of the senses, then one should be afraid and redouble one's efforts.
It is like a cowherd herding cows in a marsh. If the cows break through and trample others' crops, the cowherd is afraid that the owner will notice and take them home, so they beat them with a stick.
The next day, they are released again and return to the pasture. If the cowherd does not watch, will they know not to trample others' crops again?
At that time, the cows think:
The cowherd does not see us.
They eat others' seedlings again.
When the owner sees this, he beats them again. The cows are then afraid and dare not break through again.
The practitioner is like this. If they admonish the five faculties and do not follow desires, then they know the Way will be accomplished!

If one is tempted by the six sense objects, one should immediately restrain oneself, contemplate the suffering of the three evil paths and the difficulties of birth and death, and strive day and night, surpassing the previous by ten thousand times. What has not been attained should be accomplished, and what has been attained should be guarded against negligence.

Chapter 13: On Patience (3) The Sutra on the Concentration of Sitting Meditation, Chapter 13: On Patience. Suppose someone were to beat and scold a practitioner, at that time, the practitioner should contemplate as follows:
The insults are just sounds. Upon careful consideration, they are all empty and non-existent, arising and ceasing immediately.
It is like written characters, each with a different name. If one analyzes each character, there is no sound of scolding;

For this reason, one should subdue the inner mind, eliminate all impurities, and peacefully settle one's will, which is called practice.
Chapter 15: The Heavenly Eye Sees the End and Beginning of the Practice of the Way. The practitioner, if he is sleepy, should contemplate impermanence and death approaching soon.

Imagine wanting to see light, although the mind is dark, contemplate the three lights to make the inside and outside bright.

Contemplate the suffering of birth and death, observe the four directions with sin,

The practitioner always contemplates seeing the light, no different between day and night;

Although sleeping with eyes closed, always as if open, the vision of meditation surpasses the heavenly eye,

It is like a heavy rain suddenly clearing up. It is like a clear mirror and empty space, with heavy rain clearing up and the sun shining brightly,

The Buddha universally sees all purity, and out of compassion for the multitude, he speaks of this,

Consciousness and wisdom are the hub, quiescent and responding to conditions, without obstruction, in accord with the right path,

Observing the various kinds of music, if there is sorrow, the mind is impartial,
Hearing the sounds of the heavens, humans, and hells, with palms joined, I bow my head to the honored one of pure nature.
The practitioner, having just attained the heavenly ear, then attains penetrating hearing without disturbance.
It is like a person digging the ground in search of a treasure, originally intending to find one, but obtaining the rest of the treasure;

It is like in the middle of the night when all people are asleep, and one person alone awakens on a seven-storied tower. In the time of tranquility, he listens to various sounds, such as the music, singing and dancing, crying and lamenting, and the sound of beating drums;

The view seen by cultivating the path is also like this. From the great sÅ«tra meanings of innumerable eons, I have obtained the remaining sweet dew,

Innumerable compassionate teachings, knowing the thoughts of the assembly,

The practitioner, with the heavenly eye, sees humans and non-humans, good and evil, handsome and ugly, penetratingly observing the actions of the mind, the bright and the obscure, those with angry minds, and those with peaceful intentions.

Numerous rivers and streams, filled with the water of the YajÃ±a,

The practitioner thought to himself:

Covered by greed, anger, and delusion, driven by the staff of desire, without shame or embarrassment,

The practitioner thought to himself:

The sinful people, exhausted from pulling the carriage, will stick out their tongues. They will be injured by the whip, their bodies will be destroyed, and they will all spit blood, collapsing on the ground, their chests wounded.
Then there is a verse:
The sinful people are driven in an iron carriage, and the prison guards drive them to run;
They are beaten and whipped, spitting blood, like horses in battle with spear wounds.
If there are people who have no faith and slight goodness, they commit sinful evil and consider it to be in accordance with the Dharma;
Their evil crimes lead them into AvÄ«ci Hell, where they receive innumerable bitter sufferings.
The AvÄ«ci Hell naturally has burning charcoal and fire reaching up to the knees of the sinners, and the fire is vast without any fixed distance.

At that time, the sinners give rise to wrong thoughts and take the curved path to be a good place, and then enter the fire, burning their skin, flesh, sinews, blood vessels, and so on. As soon as they lift their feet, it returns to normal.
Then, there is a verse:
At that time, the burning charcoal and fire reach up to the knees, and after spreading out widely, the wind blows again.
When the sinners walk on it, their skin is burned and rotten. Abandoning the right path and entering the wrong path, their sins are like this.
Having escaped from this hell, not far away is the Boiling Excrement Hell, vast and boundless, with a very deep bottom. The sinners see it and think it is a bathing pool, and they say to each other:
There is a bathing pool there, with blue lotuses of five colors. We should go there to bathe and drink water to quench our thirst.

They all entered and sank to the bottom. There were various insects with mouths like iron needles that fed on flesh. They pierced the bodies of the sinners, destroying their skin and flesh. They drilled from the feet up to the head, and insects emerged from the eyes, ears, nose, and mouth.
Because the original sin had not yet been exhausted, they were not allowed to die.
Then, in verse, it says:
The results of sin lead to suffering pain. At that time, the sinners in AvÄ«ci Hell
Cry out in pain and distress, and their bodies are pinned down with iron nails.
Boiling excrement, foul and impure, vast and boundless,
Filth is all there, and the bottom is very deep.
Sinners with not a single good deed fall into this hell of King Yama.
These groups of sinners are eaten by insects with needle-like barbs.
In the hell of burning charcoal and AvÄ«ci, as well as in all the impure boiling excrement,
Falling into the flowing river, the place where sins arise, due to the retribution of past misfortune, one does not die.

Then there are two hells named Burning and Frying. At that time, the hell guardians seize the sinful people, cut them into pieces, carry them to the cauldrons and boil them, turning them over with iron spatulas and roasting them with fire.
Then there is a verse:
Having reached great suffering, in the Burning and Frying,
Those with different misfortunes among the sins then recognize their past evil deeds.
With knives, cutting them into pieces, destroying them into countless parts,
Using spatulas to burn and roast them, placing them in cauldrons to boil them.
In the Burning and Frying, detestable as flaws and afflictions,

That one who violates the precepts and destroys the Dharma will be trampled by the great elephant;
The nature of the creator is hard and stubborn, always delighting in harming sentient beings,
Eating indiscriminately, born as a city-guarding ghost.
The practitioner's mind thinks to itself:
Will I not fall into the eight hells and the sixteen divisions because of this?
Moreover, in my past lives, I have gone through these evil paths countless times. Even if I cannot fully accomplish the holy path, I will enter them again.
It is like a person who commits a heinous crime. The king orders the border officials to stab him with a spear a hundred times at dawn, a hundred times at noon, and a hundred times at dusk;
That person is stabbed three hundred times a day, his body is completely destroyed without a single intact spot, and the pain is indescribable.
Although there is this pain, compared to the torment of hell, it is millions of times worse and cannot be compared.
The pain of hell is extremely severe like this!
Then, in verse, it says:
Having committed many evils and brought this upon oneself, the poisonous pain of being seen and punished is detestable.
Seeing this suffering and distress, one should contemplate carefully and always diligently strive to quickly attain the Way.

The practitioner who establishes this stage of learning should eliminate joy and solidify the mind. If the mind is light and frivolous, one should restrain it, just as a charioteer controls a galloping chariot.
Here is a verse:
Like burning charcoal and fire, never ceasing,
One always encounters this suffering, day and night, to an immeasurable extent;
Using sharp spears and halberds, one is seen being stabbed with a hundred times the pain,
Calculating this multitude of afflictions and harm, it is not comparable to the pain of a hair in hell.
The practitioner thinks to himself:
I have not yet escaped this calamity, so I should not rejoice.
In this way, one restrains oneself and does not act lightly or frivolously. If one establishes oneself in this way, one will be able to practice single-mindedly and enter the good Dharma.
The practitioner will then tremble in fear, not violating the Dharma day and night.
Here is a verse:
Seeing decay like this, like a tree injuring itself with fruit,
And observing the accumulated dust and afflictions like a great mountain.

Single-mindedly focused on practice, abandoning joy and playfulness.
